comments.commentBody:
To Chris:
IQ isn't an important factor for doctor performance so it doesn't matter that there are more male outliers with high IQ. You don't need 140 IQ to perform your job as well as someone with a 120 IQ. Much of being a doctor is learned skill.
To Lynn:  Salaries of elite level doctors who won research awards probably are affected by skills which a high IQ would help, whereas a 120 versus 140 IQ doesn't matter for us primary docs.
To Chris: the skills that make an excellent physician, the physician's 'nose', the ability to notice the subtleties, are not measurable on I.Q. tests.

After reading a number of articles where it says that women are paid less than men I think that the salaries of every man should be reduced to what his female counterpart is paid.  Then he can see how well he can get along on 75% of his pay.  Is a woman's intellect worth less than a man's?  Are her ideas or experiments any less foolish or smart than man's?  Men may be bigger than women, have deeper voices, and do much better at certain things than women but when it comes to the average man or woman, the pay gap should not be so wide.
Oh this is hilarious!  Look what your comment did to this article?  They removed the picture of the woman holding the autorad film with this new one.

Interesting paper. I'm sure it'll be a favorite for journal clubs next fall..... One deficiency seemed to be the absence of any quantitation of the clinical burden of male versus female physician researchers. This might be hard to quantify, maybe "weekends on service/year" or "months on service/year" might be measure?? Point being that maybe there are differences in clinical duties and salary generation, outside of research funding.

Sorry, but I just HAVE to comment on the hilarious picture. Someone should have told the models that:

A) They were looking at the sequencing gel sideways. Y'all read them top to bottom.... .
B) No-one actually does manual 35S-labeled Sanger sequencing anymore.....

Alternatively, maybe they are contemporary postdocs who've never done manual sequencing. "Hey Bob, look at this artifact from the '90s that I found in a drawer!"

That is the argument used to justify paying women physicans less than their male counterpoints.
I got pregnant twice during my time as a physican faculty member, working full-time. I worked full-time until I had each child, then took 12 weeks off, then came back again full-time. I took 8 weeks vacation time (which was all my time for a whole year) and 4 weeks maternity leave. I did that twice.
I expect to work full-time as a physican for at least 30 years (ages 35-65). My dad worked full-time as a physician until age 75, so I might make 40 years.
Do you really think that taking 3 months maternity leave (2 months of which would be normal vacation time anyway) twice really should make a difference in my earning potential spread out over 30-40 years of work? That makes no sense at all!
To CA: i can't believe you got 8 weeks vacation time for working 1 year. It's extraordinary. Why can't more people get this benefit from an employer?

Rita, they constrained for time off/sick time in the study -- and still there was a discrepancy. But to your point, the workforce, regardless of industry, really doesn't accommodate families in any way -- which is another entirely.

Let's not ignore the fact that women doctors give birth a whole lot more often than male doctors. This a significant reason women in any field make less than thier male counterparts. We tend to take time off to at least give our children a good start. Many times women taken more time off than men throughout childhoods into the teenage years. We are the first to take off when family members have health issues or even when behavior or safety issues arise. Employers, even if they don't outwardly discriminate or even complain, would rather not deal with the "issue" of maternity or family leave.

Right, but its a personal choice influenced by societal expectations about gender roles, which are themselves perpetuated and enforced by the fact women have less earning capacity than men.  (A lot of couple go through this reasoning: who should be the primary caretaker and give up salary? -- oh, the person who is likely makes less in the first place. Then we blame the fact women make less than men on the fact they are primary caretakers.  This is circular)
The study did control for the number of hours worked.   They still found a gap among male and female physicians who worked the same hours.

I don't claim to have any special knowledge but of the female physicians I know, most of whom are pediatricians with young children, only one works full time. I don't know if this is the norm in other communities, but it has to significantly lower their income. However, it is quite obviously a personal choice these doctors make.

I am an independent write-in candidate for president.

My health care plan is non-partisan and beats their plan. We charge ourselves a voluntary 2 cents gratuity on every item purchased at every fast food chain and supermarket. Burger, fries and a drink is a voluntary 6 cents included in the bill. 20 items in the supermarket, is an extra 40 cents for the help.

We divide the pennies collected by the hours worked. No less than a dollar an hour per goes into Medical Assurance Savings Accounts with the lower echelon worker's names on med debit cards that goes with them when they move on. The card can be used by spouse and kids so 25 million people are covered.

We set aside $5 a week for Catastrophic Illness Pool. that's 60 million dollars a week every week in the pool for preexistings, heart transplants, accidents, etc.

We make a one line change in the tax code so med professionals can do 50 thousand a year in "charity" and take that off the top of their tax returns. Then, after all deducts, take an additional 25 K off the bottom. The med professional's goal: Freedom of Income Tax. Dr.'s and Dentists will have flashing neon signs: No insurance? I'm here!

The tax revenue loss is off set by Emergency Rooms allowed only for emergencies. Every Dr will want to do any charity treatments to lower their income taxes. Insurance co.'s and government bureaucracies are not participants in my program.

The long term solution is free medical education.

http://youtu.be/KWKMPRFNowM?hd=1.l;
Love the happy HIPPO!

Stay with the happy HIPPO, John, I feel it somehow captures you perfectly! :-)

Howie

Harold's? Never heard of it. But then it's mainly on the South Side and I don't hang out there.

But this is a Patrick Berry puzzle and X marks the spot where de sex meets the sex et.

No gimmicks. No layered themes. No hidden tricks.

Just plain good, like Harold's chicken.
This is an example of a pervasive problem in science reporting - we are told that one group is higher than another, but the magnitude of the difference is rarely spelled out, and often very small.

"For example, gap in representation in college (when computed the same way) is 25% in favor of women - more than four times as big as the pay gap discussed here."

More women are applying to college than men. There's no intentional discrimination that's stopping more men from applying, as far as I know.

If anything, women are disadvantaged in the college application process. *Acceptance rates* are quite a bit lower for girls than for boys, because the colleges are trying to keep around a 50/50% balance. I'm not saying that there shouldn't be a balance, but qualified girls are basically being denied slots just because they're female.

http://www.browndailyherald.com/female-applicants-face-lower-acceptance-...

In contrast, I can't think of too many reasons why women would be paid less for doing the *exact same work* (same medical specialty, same working hours, etc.), unless there was some kind of intentional discrimination going on.

I don't think the gender gap in college is likely the result of overt discrimination. It could be systemic discrimination in the sense that society is setup in a way that channels females towards college and men away from it. The truth is that nobody has found the gap worth studying, which is my main point with that example. The advantage goes in the "right" direction, so nobody really cares why it's there or if it could be changed.

The idea that males are advantaged in the application process is unsupported by most relevant data. The article you link could more easily be explained by the fact that greater numbers of female applicants means more from the low end of the ability distribution, relative to males. The comparable low ability males generally don't even bother applying to college. That pattern has been observed comparing high school standardized test scores to college admissions test scores, and it makes comparisons of male and female applicants misleading.

Regarding doctor pay, we don't know that these doctors were doing exactly the same work. They were equated on some dimensions, which reduced the gap from 16% to 6%. Including more alternative dimensions might have shrunk the gap further. The 6% gap may be partially or even entirely due to discrimination. But simply equating groups on some variables and relying on Argument from Incredulity that the remaining difference must be due to discrimination, though common even among scholars, is weak reasoning.

That difference is still only ~6%, which is pretty much on par with studies of gender disparities in pay in other fields after several of the biggest explanatory factors are controlled (typically a 5-9% gap remains). It's a lot when you multiply it by a doctor's salary, but it doesn't suggest doctors being unusual. I think a bigger point people ought to take away from the data is actually that it contradicts the widely held belief that most or all of the gender gap in pay is due to discrimination. This study shows clearly that most the gap is not.

All of that is not to trivialize the issue of a 6% disparity, but news stories like this are always presented as though the reader had previously believed there was no disparity and will be shocked to learn of a small one. Also, people routinely ignore even bigger sex differences when the disadvantage runs in the other direction. For example, gap in representation in college (when computed the same way) is 25% in favor of women - more than four times as big as the pay gap discussed here.

At least in the US, the blind symphony audition is standard. I'll bet the same can't be said for places like Vienna and Berlin, where the orchestras make Tea Party rallies look like diversity conventions.

What's surprising about this is that docs thought they would be immune to it.  (Do  you not live in our society?) This kind of thing has been documented across lots of professions that involve long and grueling training, where merit is supposed to be the deciding factor. The Chronicle of Higher Ed now publishes salary data for schools nationwide while actually listing average salary at a given place and rank for men and for women (because they, too, found this disparity). I read somewhere about a prestigious symphony orchestra (maybe NY?) where they started auditioning people behind a screen, so the judges really *could* only listen to the music, and ended up with a lot more women in the orchestra after that. Someone did a study about how reviewers read scholarly articles. If the author listed is a woman, the review is more likely to be critical than if the same article is presented as a man's work.  (Usually these are blind reviews in real life, but in the study they put a name on the paper and tested people's reactions.) Why would medicine be any different? Still, it's good to see this presenter at least noticing all the hedging that women tend to do in their communication. The first step is noticing it.

Alienation, born of a sudden, stark awareness of the evanescence of youth or health or life or love or happiness or freedom or whatever, which is to say, the random impermanence of life in all its all material aspects, is one way of conceptualizing your subjective experience of entrapment.
There are, of course, myriad others.
We are all condemned, prisoners of our minds, so to speak...
Certain forms of realization are sometimes emotionally too powerful to comfortably endure. The physical or psychic triggers are not limited to any one set of circumstances but rather inherent to certain facets of the human condition.
It is for such reasons that I think your opening up of your very powerful, private experiences to such a vast, anonymous public is so very worthwhile.
Your story obviously touches people very deeply. It resonates. People know and feel and care because you speak to their own experiences, whether they are momentarily healthy or not.
People may be divided by physical reality and material circumstances but they are united by certain metaphysical ones, like it or not. I feel your pain and I share your hope and your determination to survive, as do countless others, I know.
Regards...

suleika,your words are sooooo powerful,you are a true living soul...I have been seeing cancer like my guru so i was so glad that you are trying to do too...Cancer can hide so many gifts in us that we wouldnt have discovered without being ill...We all have our journeys,our way of teaching,inspiring,learning...Cancer never comes to us as one of those but i do think cancer help us teach,learn and inspire,i think cancer is a phD in wisdom!!!!!!!if we survive cancer i believe we got wiser,more wisdom to our life and we are more love and help to the ones we love....So if cancer is our journey,so let it be with wisdom,learn,inspire,share,accept,this is the way to unconditionnal peace and joy!!!!love you beautiful,christelle
Suleika, Thank you for the gift of your deeply moving posts. Your writings touch me at many levels - as a mother, a caretaker and also as a cancer survivor. Blessings to you!

"Of all you have learned..."

My dear...

Suleika,

Having been a patient in a hospital and worked as a psychologist in a psychiatric institution, I have said many times: 'When you're sick, the worst place to be in is a hospital. But, most often you must be there.'

A minor example: at 10 PM, you are sound asleep and a nurse wakes you up to give you a sleeping pill. [ I said minor.] Then after a cardiac event, when I was 38, I was hospitilized for two weeks -- three blocks from my house right in my neighborhood. When released, for the first time in my life the fresh air was no longer just part of the ambience and never even recognized. And the stunning beauty of buildings I had seen countless times. So, I understand what you wrote about in your essay.

Close to 70 years old, as I review my life... You know what? Some of the most traumatic events have tought me the most.

If I were your age and had the knowledge which I learned of the worst events of my life... Well, I would be a genius.

Having read almost all of your commentaries, this most difficult period has made you much wiser and your weekly essays make me realize that you write so well.

Yes.. "Of all you have learned..." is enormous. Use it.

Be well,

David

Thank you for your weekly post.  It is so encouraging.  I think illness teaches us very amazing lessons, like you say, your cancer is your guru.  It challenges us to all kinds of things, particularly letting go of so many preconceptions and ideas we had about ouselves and life and the world.  In some ways it is amazingly freeing.  You express these things so eloquently and with so much heart.  Keep writing please!

I use to cringe at the approach that many people take to encourage me when I had cancer. It is very burdensome to the patient, particularly the emphasis on mind over matter and the belief that one can conquer cancer through positive thinking or the correct thinking and imaging. While I did my best to eat well, take walks and enhance my immune system, even used acupuncture, there is a school of thought captured in the military terminology that did not work for me and instead made me feel guilty that I wasn't doing my best as a patient.. Even though sometimes I do not want to return to that  time and space when I went through chemo and radiation, I do enjoy reading your column and want to know that you are recovering. Even though I'm just over 50 years I feel I have had a full life and have been extremely fortunate - you are still so young and have so much more in life to enjoy.
Leapy, you speak Jabberwocky!

You must be white, upper income, baby boomer age? How else could you complain about those problems and not celebrate for the millions of Americans who benefit from being on their parents coverage, can now be covered when they are actually sick with "pre-existing" conditions, or can get legislatively affordable coverage when they are unemployed?
You must be right. Romney is the better of two evils. As opposed to raising the "age of Medicare", he'll abolish it altogether.

You do realize thatRomney has embraced the Ryan budget plan?
.
You know that bastion of fair play, and a kinder gentler way forward for the downtrodden of our nation. (End extreme sarcasm here)

Oh yes and that income disparity? The President called for an end to the totally unaffordable subsidies of the unneedy rich iit didn't happen due to Republican intransigence.

The law is still an abomination. The penalties for avoiding the mandate are low. If I understand the decision, it creates more inequality under the law for Medicaid. It relies on employers, which has the same impact and can discriminate against gays.

It is the old Puritan notion of punishing the poor for being sinful, and is combined with a policy of inegalitarianism of making the elect more elect. Under Obama, 93 percent of the increase in income in 2010 went to the top 10%, and he wants to raise the age of Medicare to 67.

It is striking how people who think Romney is awful praise Obama for taking his worst idea. It is a real condemnation of our system that Romney is the better of two evils. At least he won't raise the age of Medicare, and 93% of the increase in income may go to the top 20 percent.

Ok, now you're just being a troll.
Is one required to have an MBA to become a vegan?

Marsha -- I don't believe I am lactose intolerant; milk/cheese never made me ill as it does others I know who have been diagnosed. Until I stopped eating dairy, though, I had not realized how -- at least for me -- the dairy appeared to be connected to acid reflux, heartburn and sometimes sinus congestion.

Of course, there is no way to know how much of my improvement is attributed to which aspect, but to my mind they are all connected: Giving up dairy/meat made me feel better and also helped me cut out a lot of fat and wasted calories from my diet... which helped me lose weight... which made me a lighter runner... which motivated me to train harder.... which made me feel better about myself, etc.

The thing is -- it is so easy just to TRY it for a month and see how you feel. If you feel great -- then you can make a decision to stick with it. If you don't, then it's clearly not for you. But it's worked for me.

To Christine, congratulations on getting your time down!

If I could do that just by giving up dairy, I'd be on board in a second.

I'm curious to know if you think you are lactose intolerant?

What do you think accounts for such a huge improvement?

I was thinking more like eating an actual meal beforehand, then making do with a salad when you're out. I'm not sure you can really get around people feeling like you're judging them. There are some suggestions for dealing with that in "The Pleasure Trap." I think he suggests a more wavering attitude, e.g., "I'm just trying this now, and it seems to be working for me."

Everyone should consider learning about Scott Jurek, in addition to Ruth Heidrich. By the way, Ruth Heidrich actually put stage 4 cancer into remission for 30 years, so far with a 100% plant based diet. She skipped chemo, radiation, etc... her Oncologist tried to explain that diet had nothing to do with her cancer! He died at age 45 or so decades ago. Ruth continues to workout daily and compete at age 77. She was bold enough to "Let Food Be Thy Medicine", and she skipped the toxic stuff.

Scott Jurek's new book is excellent. "Eat And Run". He has been one of the greatest ULTRA Marathoners of our time. Vegan for about 20 years too!!

I learned to be vegan from Ruth, inspired also by Scott and the Tarahumara Indians of the Copper Canyons in Mexico ... as learned about in the best seler Born To Run. Seems that cultures, and they are rare, where they consume modest amounts of 90-100%
plant based diets are amazingly fit.

I reference a lot of great sources of injury "free" natural running in my amateur videos:

"Sh*t A Barefoot Vegan Endurance Runner Says" Parts 1&2.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yi5m0dEZMaY&feature=g-upl

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ARmAnVOeLXs

The content is all on running barefoot and VEGAN nutrition.

Plant Power!!

Happy Trails.

By the way, the 50 mile trail "race" attempt mentioned in video 1 is this Saturday... 96 degrees predicted.

Do check out Ruth Heidrich's very informative web site. Read her books as well. VERY much worth the time.

I am a 64 years old natural bodybuilder ... and for the last 2 years .. a vegan. Honestly .. i am not stronger than before .. but almost. The big improvement is that i'm almost never sick .. or simply out of breath. I fallow the advise of my "guru" on happyhealthylonglife on facebook. (vegan ..no oil)
Great article Christine .. Merci...
Daniel Groleau
I tried eating nothing but plants and grains for a week. I kept missing the meat.

I am plant based and have never felt better. No issue with recovery time, acid reflux, energy etc.

Also, my plaque is reversing less than a year after my quadruple bypass surgery. 
 
Here are the results of my last carotid artery sonogram showing plaque reversal. http://wholefed.org/2012/05/03/reversing-plaque-maybe-its-the-aluminium-...

Anyone can pick apart how long humans have been eating meat or how or brains would be the size of peas without animal protein.  There are thousands of studies and experts that will refute any effort that promotes focusing your diet on grains, vegetables & fruits.

I take 10mg of Crestor a day.  Maybe that is the cause of the Plaque reversal?  Maybe it is the baby aspirin?  Maybe it is the 30 mile run I ran on Sunday?  Maybe its the aluminium foil hat I made myself to avoid cosmic radiation…

I say: try it.  Try eating nothing but Plants & Grains for a week.  Two weeks.  One month.  Don’t tell anyone, do it for yourself.

There is no downside… only upside.

Ian Welch
Palm Beach
WholeFed.org

Ellen, I ran the 2009 palm bch marathon. Great comments.

Ian
